componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning, everyone. Today's conference call may include forward-looking statements including statements regarding Lennar's business, financial condition, results of operations, cash flows, strategies and prospects.
Forward-looking statements represent only Lennar's estimates on the date of this conference call and are not intended to give any assurance as to actual future results. Because forward-looking statements relate to matters that have not yet occurred, these statements are inherently subject to risks and uncertainties.
Many factors could affect future results and may cause Lennar's actual activities or results to differ materially from the activities and results anticipated in forward-looking statements.
These factors include those described in this morning's press release and our SEC filings, including those under the caption Risk Factors contained in Lennar's annual report on Form 10-K most recently filed with the SEC.
Please note that Lennar assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. I would like to introduce your host, Mr. Stuart Miller, CEO. Sir, you may begin.
componenttext: Thank you. I would like to introduce your host, Mr. Stuart Miller, CEO. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you, and thank you, David. And I want to say thank you to everyone for joining us this morning. This morning, I'm joined by Bruce Gross, our Chief Financial Officer. Dave Collins we just heard from an Diane Bessette, our Vice President and Tr
componenttext:
Great. Thank you, and thank you, David. And I want to say thank you to everyone for joining us this morning. This morning, I'm joined by Bruce Gross, our Chief Financial Officer. Dave Collins we just heard from an Diane Bessette, our Vice President and Treasurer; Rick Beckwitt, our President; Jon Jaffe, our Chief Financial Officer; and Jeff Krasnoff, CEO of Rialto, are here as well as some other members of our management team. Some of them will be joining in on our conversation with add -- during the Q&A period. I'm going to briefly give some remarks, as I've always done, about the business in general, and then Bruce is going to jump in, break down our financial detail and give some further guidance for next year. And then, as always, we will open up to Q&A. 
We would like to request, as well we always do, that during the Q&A period, each of our participants, please limit yourself to one question and one follow-up so that we can get as many participants as possible.
So let me go ahead and begin and say that our second quarter 2016 results reflect another quarter of strong operating results for our company. We've continued to benefit from a slow and steady housing market recovery that has continued to define the U.S. housing market environment. And we've crafted specific strategies within our company for our business that have positioned us well to maximize opportunity in these market conditions. 
As we've noted consistently over the past years, the overall housing market has been generally defined by a rather large production deficit that has continue to grow over the past year's. While questions had been raised as to the real normalized levels of production that are required to serve the U.S. current population, we believe that production levels in the 1 million to 1.2 million starts per year range are still too low for the needs of American household growth that is now normalizing. While measuring current production levels against historical norms of 1.5 million starts per year might be flawed logic as there may be a new normal, we believe this of every low inventory levels in existing and new homes and the low vacancy rate and high and growing rental rates for apartments indicate that we are in short supply nationally. With that said, it's important to note that the housing market is not really a national market. Instead, it's a large number of very local markets each with different dynamics that are averaged together to generate some sometimes quirky results. 
With that said, we believe that there continues to be out growing pent-up demand for dwellings of all types across the country, though stronger in some markets than others, in this demand will continue to propel a continued, long cycle, slow and steady market improvement. 
While demand has been constrained by limited access to mortgages, stronger general economic condition, including lower unemployment, modest wage growth and general consumer confidence, are still driving consumers to form new households and to purchase homes and to rent apartments. We expect that demand will continue to build and come to the market over the next years and that will drive increased production as the deficit and housing stock ultimately needs to be replenished. Nevertheless,, land and labor shortages will continue to be limiting factors and will constrained supply and restrict the ability to quickly respond to growing demand while the mortgage markets in higher rents will continue to constrain in that demand.
We expect that these conditions will continue to result in a slow and steady positive homebuilding market and will enable slow steady, though sometimes erratic growth, throughout the industry. This has been our consistent guiding theme over the past years, and we have mapped our strategy around this view. 
Each segment of our company has positioned itself for continued performance in 2016 and beyond, and we believe that we remain well-positioned to execute our operating plans and strategies in each of the segments. And then with the somewhat erratic conditions that defined in the early part of this year, we have remained resolute in our view that have generated our strategy. 
Against this backdrop, let me briefly discuss each of our operating segments. Our for-sale homebuilding operations experience in the healthy spring selling season with the sales base of 3.9 sales per month per community. Our results reflect the slow but steady growth in the overall homebuilding market I us our new home orders increased 10% year-over-year while community count grew 4% and our average sales price grew 4% to $362,000. 
Even while continued labor shortages and land and construction cost increases have tested our ability to mac's sales and delivery pace, our management team has carefully managed sales prices, maximize margins and focus on reducing SG&A to offset and maintain a strong net operating margin, which came in at 13.9%. As we've noted in past conference calls, we have adjusted our for-sale housing strategy as the recovery has matured and then pricing has adjusted to that recovery. There are 3 components of our core homebuilding segment strategy. They are: Soft pivot; slower growth; and focus on SG&A.
To begin, we've talked consistently about our soft pivot land strategy over the past years, away from the land-heavy acquisition strategy in the early stages of the recovery. And we are now targeting land acquisitions with the shorter 2 to 3-year average life. Our more recent quarterly reports have demonstrated that we've moderated our land spend as a percent of homebuilding revenues. And this has, and we'll continue to be, a core strategy driving our homebuilding platform as we manage land acquisitions to taper the growth rate in both community count and home sales. 
Second, we've noted in past quarter conference call that given our and now mature recovery, we have been and continue to carefully manage and limit our growth in order to grow the bottom line and to drive strong cash flow. We have moderated our topline growth targets to a chief our growth rate in the 7% to 10% range as we've redirected our management efforts towards maximizing our net operating margin. Third, with less pressure on the topline growth rate, we can intensify management focus on driving faster bottom line growth and cash flow by maximizing pricing power and using innovative strategies to drive our SG&A down. 
Under the company mantra of what we can measure we can change, we are focused on changing and improving all elements of our operation. As an example, last quarter, we highlighted that we've been working on reducing customer acquisition cost. We've been moving our advertising and marketing spend away from conventional marketing like newspaper and billboard advertising to a purely digital platform. 
In the current quarter's results, we're continuing to see the benefit of this management focus as a significant portion of our SG&A reduction can be attributed to this initiative. It is noteworthy that this quarter's SG&A of 9.3% is the lowest second quarter SG&A in our company's history. With demand growing steadily, land limited, labor tight and constrained mortgage availability, we believe that our three-pronged strategy for our homebuilding segment positions us well for this slow but steady growth environment. We feel that we can 1 our business at a steady and consistent growth rate with strong bottom line profitability and cash flow by measuring and changing our way to greater efficiency and performance in our core for-sale homebuilding segment.
Moving on, our financial services group has an outstanding second quarter as well. While the Financial Services operations have grown alongside our core homebuilding business, we've also benefited from a strong, though sometimes erratic, we find market as well as from the expansion of retail opportunities in both our mortgage and titled platforms. These sidecar opportunities are continuing to expand as we move through 2016. Our strategies for the future of Lennar Financial Services continues to be to continue to construct and maintain a fully self-sufficient Financial Services platform that benefits from Lennar homebuilding business but drives profitability from retail operations as well. Bruce Gross oversees this operation and will discuss this further in his comments. 
Next, our Multifamily program continues to develop as a leading blue-chip developer of apartment communities across the country. The second quarter has continued an outstanding run for LMC, Lennar Multifamily Communities, which continues to complement our for-sale homebuilding operation. Since household formation has recovered as a slower rate than expected and many new households have been more inclined to rent than purchase, we have focused on building well located rental communities to address this market opportunity. First-time home purchasers have come back to the market more slowly than they have historically and more slowly than expected. While approximately 30% of our for-sale homebuilding business continues to be geared to first-time home purchases, our broader new household strategy has targeted the rental market as well.
As we've continued to expand our national footprint, we've matured and evolved from a merchant build program, which was designed to prove our base concept. This beginning phase work extremely well as we have proven our ability to purchase, design, build, stabilize and sell a number of our communities at a growing level of profitability. Having proven in the concept, we have no built were added a build to core platform. This platform enables us to build and retain our outstanding pipeline of properties and benefit from long-term ownership. We have now waste $2 billion for our build to core platform, which will become a long-term cash flow producing fee generating value creation machine. 
And while Multifamily production has generally normalized more rental product -- has generally normalized more rental product is going to continue to be needed, and we are very well-positioned to continue to be careful and site selection while we feel this need and grow our Multifamily platform. Our now almost $7 billion plus apartment strategy is proving to be very well-timed as rental rates continue to climb and vacancies are at very low levels. 
Next, our Rialto segment continued to see challenges of the second quarter. While our Rialto segment continued to see challenges in the second quarter, we continue to see opportunity rising in our asset management business as we get closer to realizing the embedded value of our promote from our Rialto fund investments. We expect to begin to report our promote in the first half of 2017. Additionally, on a current basis, our fund and asset management business showed improved profitability over last year's second quarter, and we expect this trend to continue. 
Unfortunately, volatility within of the capital markets in the first quarter continue to pressure volumes and pricing on new issue commercial mortgage-backed securities into the second quarter, and that continued to negatively impact our mortgage finance business. Nevertheless, while Rialto Mortgage Finance was less of a contributor in the current period than in past quarters, we have been seeing sequential improvement in both volumes and margins for RMF and the capital markets have generally healed, and we expect to improve -- improvement and contributions in the second half of the year. 
Rialto also suffered a one-time write-off resulting from a discrete single assets from a bulk legacy acquisition in 2010. Overall, our Rialto platform enables us to invest across all real estate and financial products and allows us to capitalize on both short-term and long-term duration opportunities throughout the economic cycles. 
While the collapse of the capital markets in the beginning of the calendar year and the one-time water from a single asset negatively impacted year-to-date earnings for Rialto, this volatility has also created unique opportunities for new investments in our asset management business. The dysfunction in the financial market, along with new risk retention rules and banking regulations, will ultimately work to the benefit of Rialto's core competence in CMBS and financial products, and we will continue to grow as the best-in-class asset manager.
And finally, as we noted in our press release, we've successfully completed an important step in the evolution of FivePoint, our strategic large-scale community builder. We contribute and exchanged our interest in 3 strategic joint ventures and our interests in the management company for an investment in the newly formed entity called FivePoint Holdings LLC. This transaction marks the next step in FivePoint's evolution as a strategic developer and manager of large-scale, master-planned communities. It also marks a next step in Lennar's strategic mission to revert to our core homebuilding base. As the recovery matures, FivePoint will operate very independently with a self-contained management team led by Emil Haddad. We simply could not be more excited about the prospects for the future of this one-of-a-kind leader in community development. 
Overall and in conclusion, let me say that we continue to be very pleased to present our second quarter results and our overall progress of this morning. We feel very confident that our view of the market and the strategies that define our business segments have worked very well to position us for continued performance and future growth. And as I said many times before, we are extremely confident that we have the right people, the right programs and the right timing to continue to perform this year and into the future. Now let me turn it over to Bruce.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Stuart, and good morning. Our net earnings for the second quarter were $218 million, which is a 19% increase over the prior year. Revenues from home sales increased 17% in the second quarter, driven by a 12% increase in wholly-owned deliveries and
componenttext:
Thanks, Stuart, and good morning. Our net earnings for the second quarter were $218 million, which is a 19% increase over the prior year. Revenues from home sales increased 17% in the second quarter, driven by a 12% increase in wholly-owned deliveries and a 4% year-over-year increase in average selling price to $362,000. 
Our gross margin on home sales in the second quarter was 23.1%, which was in line with our stated goals. The prior year's gross margin percentage was 23.8%. The gross margin defined year-over-year was due primarily to increased land costs. Sales incentives continued to decline as this quarter was 5.7% versus 5.8% in the prior year. Gross margin percent were once again the highest in the East and West regions. 
Direct construction cost increases have moderated compared to the prior year. These costs were up 2% year-over-year to approximately $53 per square foot, driven entirely by labor an offset by a slight decrease in material cost. As Stuart highlighted, we were successful in improving our SG&A operating leverage by growing volume organically in our existing homebuilding divisions, and we continued to see the benefits of our focus on digital marketing. As a result, operating margins improved year-over-year by 10 basis points. 
Equity and loss from unconsolidated subs was $9.6 million in the second quarter compared to equity in earnings of $6.5 million in the prior year. The loss was primarily attributable to the company's share of costs associated with establishing the new FivePoint entity, partially offset by $6.7 million of equity and earnings from one of our unconsolidated entities primarily due to the sale of homesites to third parties. 
Other income was $14.9 million, primarily due to a profit participation from one of our joint ventures, and there is a partial offset of $7 million in the noncontrolling interest line. We opened 88 new communities in the quarter with 692 net active communities. New home orders increased 10% and new order dollar value increased 11% for the quarter. The cancellation rate decreased to 14% in the second quarter from 15% in the prior year. In the second quarter, we purchased 5,300 homesites, totaling $437 million versus $445 million in the prior year's quarter. These numbers aligned with our soft pivot strategy where we're focused on writing shorter duration land. Our homesites owned and controlled now total 166,000 homesites, of which 131,000 are owned and 35,000 are controlled. Our completed unsold inventory ended the quarter with approximately 1,200 homes, which is in our normal range of 1 to 2/3 community.
Turning to Financial Services. This business segment had strong results this quarter with operating earnings of $44.1 million compared to $39.1 million in the prior year. Mortgage pretax income increased to $36.8 million from $33.5 million in the prior year. Mortgage originations were flat with the prior year at $2.4 billion. The improved earnings is driven by an increase profit per alone due to the favorable interest rate environment. Refinance volume for the company decreased to 12% of total originations from 19% in the prior year, bringing this quarter's purchase origination volume to 88% of total originations. The capture rate of Lennar homebuyers improved to 83% this quarter from 82% in the prior year. Our title company's profit also increased growing to $7.4 million in the quarter from $5.1 million in the prior year primarily due to higher profit per transaction versus the prior year. 
Turning to Rialto. This segment produced an operating loss of $13.8 million compared to operating earnings of $7.6 million in the prior year. Both amounts are a net of noncontrolling interest. The investment management business contributed $26.1 million of earnings, which includes $6.9 million of equity and earnings in the real estate funds and $19.2 million of management fees and other. 
At quarter-end, the undistributed hypothetical carried interest for Rialto Real Estate Funds 1 and 2 now totals $138 million. Rialto Mortgage Finance operations contributed $386 billion of commercial loans into 3 securitizations resulting in earnings of $12.7 million compared with $721 million and $29 million in the prior year, respectively, and these are before their G&A expenses. 
As mentioned previously, the volume decrease was due to the disruption in the CMBS capital markets earlier this year and has taken some time for the new home market to ramp back up. Our direct investments had a loss of $21 million. This included a $16 million write-off of uncollectible receivables at a hospital acquired through the foreclosure of the distressed loan from a 2010 bank portfolio acquisition. A third-party management company operates this hospital. Rialto's G&A and other expenses were $24.9 million for the quarter and interest expense were $6.7 million. Rialto ended the quarter with a strong liquidity position with $104 million of cash. 
The Multifamily segment delivered a $14.9 million operating profit in the quarter, primarily driven by the segment's $15.4 million share of the gain from the sales and operating property and a $5.2 million gain on a third-party land sale, as well as management fee income, partially offset by G&A expenses. 
We ended the quarter with 8 completed and operating properties and 32 under construction, 5 of which are in lease up totaling over 9,700 apartments total development cost of approximately $2.6 billion. Including these communities, we had a diversified development pipeline that exceeds $7 billion in over 25,000 apartments. 
Our tax rate for the quarter was 32.2%. The lower rate is a result of our continuing efforts to maximize the new home energy efficiency credit, which was again extended into 2016. The tax rate for future quarters should be approximately 34%. Although we will continue to focus on trying to maximize of this available energy credit. 
Turning to the balance sheet. Liquidity remained strong with approximately $600 million of homebuilding cash and $375 million of borrowings under our $1.6 billion revolving credit facility. Our leverage improved by 390 basis points year-over-year as our homebuilding net debt to total capital was reduced to 43.5%. We grew stockholder's equity by 19% to $6.1 billion and our book value per share increased to 27.92 per share. 
In March, we issued $500 million of 5-year senior notes at 4.75%. And in April, we retired our maturing 6.5% senior notes. In May, we converted the remaining $71 million of our 2.75% convertible notes. And in addition, during the quarter, we early converted approximately $68 million of our 3.25% convertible senior notes with an additional $136  million [ph] converted subsequent to quarter end.
Finally, I would like to update our 2016 goals. 2016 homebuilding goals are right on track with the guidance that we gave at the start of the year was just a couple of quarterly refinements. First, deliveries. 
Deliveries are still on track to be between 26,500 and 27,000 homes for all of 2016. The backlog conversion ratio in the second quarter was 88%, which exceeded the previous guidance of 80% to 85%. We capitalized on a healthy spring selling season and sold and delivered some homes in Q2 that were scheduled for our third quarter. Given that, we now expect our backlog conversion ratio to be around 75% in the third quarter. 
The fourth quarter is still projected to achieve a backlog conversion of at least 90%. Operating margins are still on track to be flat to down 50 basis points for the entire year. The gross margin percent will vary between Q3 and Q4 based on our product mix. Q3 is expected to be between 22.5% and 23%, while the fourth quarter is projected to be between 23.5% and 24%. 
We are still on track to achieve the lowest SG&A in our company's history for the full year with the greatest leverage coming in our fourth quarter. 
Turning to Financial Services. We are assuming we will continue to benefit from the extended low interest rate environment, and we are increasing our Financial Services goal to $130 million tell $135 million of profit for all of 2016. 
Turning to Rialto. We are still on track to growing between $15 million and $20 million for 2016. However, the one-time write-off of the hospital receivables will now bring the range to flat to $5 million of profit for the full year and is still weighted more heavily towards the fourth quarter. 
We are still on track with $50 million to $55 million of profit in the Multifamily segment with the third quarter close to breakeven and strong profit in the fourth quarter. The category of joint ventures, land sales and other income, we expect to be flattish for the third quarter. But now expect the fourth quarter to be the highest profit quarter for this category through 2016 with $20 million to $30 million of profit. 
And finally, our balance sheet is well on its way on its Ted to lower leverage. The soft pivot strategy, the strong earnings contribution and the 400 million 3.25% convertible securities, of which half has already converted through mid-June, should bring us to a net debt-to-total capital in debt 35% to 40% range by year-end. This will position us extremely well as we finish out 2016. 
Let me turn it back to the operator to open it up for questions.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Ivy Zelman of Zelman & Associates.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Ivy Zelman of Zelman & Associates.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016

And where you're exceeding and just reinitiating between price point because there is some concern around moderation at the high, where is in the lower price point seem to be very much accelerating. So that's my first, and I have a follow-up.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, good. I'm going to turn over to Rick and Jon. But I want to correct one thing that I apparently said. Jon is not the Chief Financial Officer of the company. He's the Chief Operating Officer. And I didn't want to dethrone Bruce inadvertently. So let
componenttext: Okay, good. I'm going to turn over to Rick and Jon. But I want to correct one thing that I apparently said. Jon is not the Chief Financial Officer of the company. He's the Chief Operating Officer. And I didn't want to dethrone Bruce inadvertently. So let me turn it over to Jon and Rick to give some color on that.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi, this is Jon. Overall we saw there strong sales in different markets that tend to cover both starter price points and move up price points. For example, Pacific Northwest were strong across all segments. Southern California was strong. Southeast, the S
componenttext:
Hi, this is Jon. Overall we saw there strong sales in different markets that tend to cover both starter price points and move up price points. For example, Pacific Northwest were strong across all segments. Southern California was strong. Southeast, the Southwest quarter were strong. Charlotte in the Carolinas also strong and Central Valley, which is a more affordable price point for California. 
The place that was off the most was Houston as you would expect, as you continue to see the effects of the job loss there. And you see that also with our greatest increase in incentives in Houston even though for the overall company were flat. So if you look at it big picture. Florida was year-over-year sort of flat for us in absorption pace. It for now, flat. Texas, excluding Euston actually improved, pricing in the Carolinas were improved. And clearly, we to see some lower demand in the higher price points as compared to lower price points. But generally, it's still some market-driven.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's really helpful. And then just, secondly, on respect to the Multifamily portfolio and recognizing the strength of what you're seeing. Can you talk a little bit about the lease-ups, if they're meeting expectations. There is concern that we all been t
componenttext: That's really helpful. And then just, secondly, on respect to the Multifamily portfolio and recognizing the strength of what you're seeing. Can you talk a little bit about the lease-ups, if they're meeting expectations. There is concern that we all been talking about on the urban supply and a lot of supply that might be a bit of a Head of Skis and how you think about your investment and your growth in that sector in that overall category going forward with respect to the supply dynamics.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ivy, it's Rick. First, I'd tell you that we couldn't be, from our standpoint, better position. And you got to go back in time. We started this program back in 2011, and a lot of the pipeline was secured at points in time where there wasn't a lot of people
componenttext: Ivy, it's Rick. First, I'd tell you that we couldn't be, from our standpoint, better position. And you got to go back in time. We started this program back in 2011, and a lot of the pipeline was secured at points in time where there wasn't a lot of people looking for a land opportunity and it's coming through the -- it's coming through our machine right now. We've got huge strategy. The merchant Philp strategy, where we're going to sell those assets and generate good, consistent profits were else as the company. And our build the core strategy gives us the opportunity to hold onto these assets for a longer period of time because it's in a longer growth vehicle. As you look at the things that we've put under contract, we were very careful in, first of all, understanding with their growth of the market was going to be, focus and vacancy levels, focusing on each of products that was close to our assets. So just like in our homebuilding business, we're very specific on identifying where things are going to come on and compete. And I can tell you, looking across of the portfolio, we really could be better positioned.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me jump in here, ivy, and say that I think that we had at the outset a strategic advantage. We started with an overlay of homebuilding operations, where we had market data and market intelligence. We understood that we were not dealing with a national
componenttext: Let me jump in here, ivy, and say that I think that we had at the outset a strategic advantage. We started with an overlay of homebuilding operations, where we had market data and market intelligence. We understood that we were not dealing with a national apartment market or for-sale markets for that matter, but we were dealing with local markets, and each one would have to be regarded carefully and individually. We mapped out our strategy for investments, for land acquisition. We were careful to avoid markets that look like they were becoming oversaturated. I think Rick and Jon and the entire Multifamily team did an extraordinary job of finding the opportunities where growth would be consistent and where we would have long dated opportunities for a sustained business. And given the fact that we had a very deep research team already established that had an eye towards, not just the rental markets, but also the for-sale markets we think gave us a better window into the market and better strategic positioning. There is a lot of talk about the urban markets being somewhat overbuilt. In most of those instances, those were the markets where we saw the most action and where we didn't get heavily involved or where we did we got involved very early and very attractive pricing. So I think that we are starting to hear, everybody is starting to hear that there might be a little bit more heat in some of the rental markets. What I've heard articulated by one of the best and brightest in the rental market is that we're probably coming to the later innings of a doubleheader, the first game of a doubleheader. We might see a little bit of softness for a period of time. But it looks like and it feels like absorption is going to outstrip any kind of oversupply in fairly short order. And we think that there's a lot of run rates for the Multifamily markets -- for the rental markets going forward.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Ivy, the last thing on that if we are in that stage with that market gets a little bit soft and that -- and what's that going to do is it's going to drive some of the people out of the market. And given the fact that we just created this $2 billion ve
componenttext: And Ivy, the last thing on that if we are in that stage with that market gets a little bit soft and that -- and what's that going to do is it's going to drive some of the people out of the market. And given the fact that we just created this $2 billion venture, it's going to position us to really capitalize on the opportunity that people step away from the market. So we're really excited at where we are.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Michael Rehaut of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Next question comes from Michael Rehaut of JPMorgan.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The first question I had was on the -- just another type of broader health question on the general markets. Ivy refer to kind of the higher end. But I was hoping to get a little more color around what's going on in your California markets and kind of spea
componenttext: The first question I had was on the -- just another type of broader health question on the general markets. Ivy refer to kind of the higher end. But I was hoping to get a little more color around what's going on in your California markets and kind of speak to the coastal versus Inland Empire and you mentioned Central Valley. If we can kind of get a little more in-depth look on the different trends, different markets and again, maybe speaking to high end versus low-end and the foreign buyer. There's, always, I think, a good amount of interest in those trends.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Jon again. Now, California as I said a moment ago, is sat from a sales perspective remain strong year-over-year. And we see a pace of overall 5 sales per community per month on average. Certainly, at the lower price point, it absorbs faster.
componenttext: Sure. This is Jon again. Now, California as I said a moment ago, is sat from a sales perspective remain strong year-over-year. And we see a pace of overall 5 sales per community per month on average. Certainly, at the lower price point, it absorbs faster. So California, in general, though, it's hard to produce homes at the lower price points because not only at land costs, but also because of impact piece being as significant as they are. But that tends to drive, particularly in Southern California, the Bay Area, a higher sales point. And that higher sales price point clearly, it's hard to get significant momentum above looking at the current levels. We are seeing sustained interest particularly in the Asian or Chinese buyer. We haven't seen that fall off. So if you look at a place like Irvine, where's it's been very significant, we have a good day at the great Park. That's remained very consistent and healthy. Same thing in the Bay Area marketplace. So we're seeing consistency there. Bakersfield probably is off the most in terms of California markets. It's emerge in Houston. It's not as severe their us all back in the energy sector, which is a lot of the job creations that has been in Bakersfield has been job loss in Bakersfield, remains healthy, though, from a Central Valley perspective.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just secondly, on the second half of the year, obviously, a lot of detailed guidance and really appreciate the help there. But no good deeds goes unturned, unpunished. Just a little more clearly, if possible. The ASP for the back half of the year
componenttext: And then just secondly, on the second half of the year, obviously, a lot of detailed guidance and really appreciate the help there. But no good deeds goes unturned, unpunished. Just a little more clearly, if possible. The ASP for the back half of the year, you did 3 65 in the first quarter, 3 62 in the second. Your average price in backlog is in the high 3 60s. So can we expect something similar to persist into the back half?

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, this is Bruce. I would say that because the mix of what's in the backlog includes a little bit more of lower price zones, you'll likely to see the average sales price come down into the 3 50s in the back half of the year.
componenttext: Mike, this is Bruce. I would say that because the mix of what's in the backlog includes a little bit more of lower price zones, you'll likely to see the average sales price come down into the 3 50s in the back half of the year.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Susan Maklari of EPS.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Susan Maklari of EPS.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: You obviously have realized a lot of benefits in what you've been doing through your marketing initiative in the SG&A that result this quarter. But looking out from there, how do we think about what the next steps are and what are the things you take adva
componenttext: You obviously have realized a lot of benefits in what you've been doing through your marketing initiative in the SG&A that result this quarter. But looking out from there, how do we think about what the next steps are and what are the things you take advantage of continue to kind of see improvements in there?

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the example of migrating from conventional to digital marketing is put forth simply as an example. We have initiatives throughout our organization that are designed to use technologies to change the landscape of the way that we are operating our bus
componenttext:
Well, the example of migrating from conventional to digital marketing is put forth simply as an example. We have initiatives throughout our organization that are designed to use technologies to change the landscape of the way that we are operating our business. Some other examples of that are as simple as in and around technology. We are revamping the entire plumbing system of our technology department to reconfigure in a more efficient manner the way that we input information and ultimately produce reports for people in the field. That seems kind of simplistic. But in a company like ours that has evolved systems over a lot of years, going back and reconfiguring systems with a proper tubing system enables us to reduce of the number of applications that we're actually using in the field with multiple points of input to drive efficient export of data to the people that need to use it on a regular basis. It will enable us to be more accurate. It'll enable us to be a lot more timely approaching real-time distribution of data over the next year or 2. This will, that initiative alone will drive cost down. We view that over the next couple of years, there's a 20 to 50 basis point reduction in SG&A that we'll derive just from that. Now there might be some intermittent takes up in cost, but primarily, the trend will be down. 
In our production arena, we are using our technologies to look at the number of models and the efficiency of the plan designs that we're offering our customers in the field. We're looking at technologies to review and to consolidate the view of SKUs that we're offering across our different markets. All of these things, we view as opportunities to bring another 10, 20, 50 basis points to either the reduction of SG&A or potentially the efficiency of our construction efforts.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just in terms of the sort of labor side. I know that you noted that you costs was up 2% I think that in the quarter. We are hearing that in some areas perhaps things are getting a bit better there. Can you just give us more detail on what you've
componenttext: And then just in terms of the sort of labor side. I know that you noted that you costs was up 2% I think that in the quarter. We are hearing that in some areas perhaps things are getting a bit better there. Can you just give us more detail on what you've seen?

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Jon. I wouldn't describe conditions are better. What you see a change as the construction cycle moves into this part of the year. So you see more stress perhaps in the drywall area today than you did before and perhaps less stress at the front end
componenttext: This is Jon. I wouldn't describe conditions are better. What you see a change as the construction cycle moves into this part of the year. So you see more stress perhaps in the drywall area today than you did before and perhaps less stress at the front end with labs. But overall, it remains very constrained. All of the increase for us was in the labor category. In fact, because of the low point of lumber in our deliveries in Q2, actually material costs were down for us in year-over-year. So still can see pressure in labor. And that ties into the point Stuart was making. We are very focused on doing a better job of our tools communicating with our labor force so that we can communicate jobsite readiness and their availability and be very [indiscernible] trade partners.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016

componenttext: Next question comes from the line of Robert Wetenhall of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016

componenttext: This is actually Michael Mike on for Rob today. It just a quick question for you guys. Looking at some of the transducing quarter on a quarter over quarter on your orders and demand, I was wondering if any of the strength in the Central market or kind of slowed down in the West and some other regions, is it due to a change into a discount in footprint as opposed to just organic demand? And if you guys could touch of some of the markets that have been outlays versus, either strength or weaknesses, greatly appreciate it.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this is Jon. Again, the biggest needle mover was the decline in sales pace in Houston when you look at the essential other markets in the Central saw an improvement in Phoenix and Dallas has remained very strong and improved year-over-year in terms
componenttext: Well, this is Jon. Again, the biggest needle mover was the decline in sales pace in Houston when you look at the essential other markets in the Central saw an improvement in Phoenix and Dallas has remained very strong and improved year-over-year in terms of sales pace. And the West, it fluctuates very much based on community openings. So for example, the Bay area, which remains very strong was down year-over-year that's just based on timing. We went from an absorption of over 7 sales per month per community to 5. 5 is very healthy, but no, I'll just say that's just depending on timing of the communities and very similar throughout the rest of California.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016

componenttext: So thinking about timing for the remainder of the year, would you expect restaurants to continue to persist a real additional communities, want to market that will help benefit of those rates in the region?

componenttext: I think in general, you'll see as municipality struggle to deal with the increase in activity, a slowness in bringing communities online. So I think you'd expect that trend to continue somewhat.

componenttext: I'll just add that if you look at Central activity, our sales were up 22% year-over-year for the quarter. We've got some communities that were held back because of weather. That was really that in parts of the central U.S. So you'll start to see those. End of this quarter, beginning in next.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of John Lovallo of Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of John Lovallo of Merrill Lynch.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The first question is on the operating margin outlook to be flat to down 50 basis points year-over-year. And this is despite 20 basis points of improvement in the first quarter and about 10 in the second quarter. Understand as the third quarter gross marg
componenttext: The first question is on the operating margin outlook to be flat to down 50 basis points year-over-year. And this is despite 20 basis points of improvement in the first quarter and about 10 in the second quarter. Understand as the third quarter gross margin expectations seem to be a bit tempered. But it just seems that the leverage of that you should get on the higher volume in the back half of the year could be an upset. So it just feels like there might be live conservatism baked in there. Can you help me understand that?

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jon, this is Bruce. As you look at in the prior year, we had some pretty strong operating margins, especially in the third quarter, as you're looking at year-over-year and then the fourth quarter. So as you're looking at any change in volume, our thi
componenttext: Yes, Jon, this is Bruce. As you look at in the prior year, we had some pretty strong operating margins, especially in the third quarter, as you're looking at year-over-year and then the fourth quarter. So as you're looking at any change in volume, our third quarter won't have as much increase in volume as our fourth quarter is likely to have year-over-year. So there's not much leverage there. So we are not trying to be conservative. I think as we've laid out in this guidance and dated quarter-to-quarter, this is what we really think is going to come in. So, as you do the math with those numbers, I think you'll see us right in that range. There's no conservatism of that we're trying to put into the guidance that were given.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then the follow-up would be realizing that Houston still been a challenging market with oil kind of creeping back in this $50 per barrel range, how is the mood then? I mean, are you guys seeing signs that as things could be at least bottoming?
componenttext: And then the follow-up would be realizing that Houston still been a challenging market with oil kind of creeping back in this $50 per barrel range, how is the mood then? I mean, are you guys seeing signs that as things could be at least bottoming?

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we are you seeing signs of that. The biggest issue associated with Houston right now is serious still seeing positive employment growth. The issues that, that growth is really happening as the lower wage job as supposed to the higher wage job. Drivin
componenttext: Yes, we are you seeing signs of that. The biggest issue associated with Houston right now is serious still seeing positive employment growth. The issues that, that growth is really happening as the lower wage job as supposed to the higher wage job. Driving that or stemming from that are lower priced homes. And we have a lot of amenities in Houston and that our focus on a lower price are doing extremely well. It's really once you get above that $400,000 price point in the oil quarter where sales are off. And if you were to break out our business between our higher price and our lower price, what's dragging Houston down is the higher price community. That being said, we've got some core assets that are low land basis that we're just hanging onto and metering out so sales to the buyers that are there. We are seeing rig counts slow, decline in rig counts slow down. You're starting to see a little bit more relow activity or talk of reload to be as oil engines back up. And it moves above 50, 55, I think you'll start to see an overall change in temperament throughout the market.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of Judah Rahmani of KBW.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of Judah Rahmani of KBW.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a broad strategic question. As Lennar family of companies has expanded, has your vision for the company to evolve until more of a real estate asset manager Brookfield of company? Or do you see the company remaining at its core, homebuilder with other
componenttext: Just a broad strategic question. As Lennar family of companies has expanded, has your vision for the company to evolve until more of a real estate asset manager Brookfield of company? Or do you see the company remaining at its core, homebuilder with other but perhaps fewer related option businesses? You mentioned with FivePoint the potential for simplification.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, our strategy, and we've been talking about it for some time now, is with the maturity of the market, we're clearly focused on reverting to our core, what we almost call reverting to pure play. We think that the development of some of these strategic
componenttext: Yes, our strategy, and we've been talking about it for some time now, is with the maturity of the market, we're clearly focused on reverting to our core, what we almost call reverting to pure play. We think that the development of some of these strategic ancillary businesses were very much a part of growing the core out of the downturn and leveraging opportunities that were part of our D&A. But having developed those strategies to elements of maturity, we think that there are opportunities that we have maintained as optional opportunities for those businesses to find better programs for themselves. You see that embedded in the way that FivePoint has been evolving. If you look at the management team of FivePoint, led by Emil Haddad, who we have been working -- he's been working within the company for over 20 years. The management team is a self-sufficient, independent, highly confident, industry-leading management team that's prepared to operate very independently. And as has been reported, we have been looking at an opportune time to integrate an IPO. The market doesn't happen to be there. But with that said, it's emblematic of the strategies that we've employed. Jeff Krasnoff leads Rialto. Rialto has it self-sufficient team. And of course, as we've talked about quite a lot on this call, our Multifamily program, LMC, is also led by Todd Farrell, very strong leader with a core management team that it too is operating very independently. So while under the one R umbrella, we all tend to drive and work well together. And synergistically, the core mission right now is to revert to pure play as a homebuilder and to ultimately, over the next years, as opportunities percent of themselves, find proper homes for those opportunities.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the Rialto side, with risk retention quickly approaching on the horizon for the end of this year, are you viewing that as an opportunity? And specifically, is there an opportunity to raise funds that would be? Are you seeing demand from institutional i
componenttext: On the Rialto side, with risk retention quickly approaching on the horizon for the end of this year, are you viewing that as an opportunity? And specifically, is there an opportunity to raise funds that would be? Are you seeing demand from institutional investors to participate in risk retention funds?

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, we've talked about that a number of times. And look, Rialto has some of its legacy assets that came about in the beginnings of the recovery are a minor drag to an operation. But the big bold opportunity is this blue-chip operating machine that
componenttext: Well, look, we've talked about that a number of times. And look, Rialto has some of its legacy assets that came about in the beginnings of the recovery are a minor drag to an operation. But the big bold opportunity is this blue-chip operating machine that we have built as an asset manager and as a conduit business. That business is really well-crafted to participate in this ultra regulatory environment that we have run into, where both bank regulation, whether it's Basel III or Dodd-Frank and risk retention rules, all kind of migrate business in the direction of the platform that we've built. And over time, Rialto is going to benefit from this thing as well position. The money that we have raised is clearly earmarked for those [indiscernible] and eventually a real confident for the opportunity set that lies ahead.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of Mike Dahl of Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of Mike Dahl of Credit Suisse.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question, just to pick up on the, some of the FivePoint comments. Just maybe some clarification there. I think the original intent was that this formal combination was conditioned on an actual IPO. So just curious if the overall structure is the sam
componenttext: First question, just to pick up on the, some of the FivePoint comments. Just maybe some clarification there. I think the original intent was that this formal combination was conditioned on an actual IPO. So just curious if the overall structure is the same. Your ownership interests is to the same as originally concentrated. What's the rationale for going ahead and formally converting the interest today. And then it looked like you recognize some costs alongside at this quarter. So how should we think about any P&L impact over the next couple of quarters related to this?

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think in a general sense, the transaction is very similar. As is widely known, the IPO market has been tepid at best. It's just not the opportune time. But the strategy of putting together FivePoint and large scale communities under one umbrella managem
componenttext: I think in a general sense, the transaction is very similar. As is widely known, the IPO market has been tepid at best. It's just not the opportune time. But the strategy of putting together FivePoint and large scale communities under one umbrella management team was a strategy that was primary under any circumstances. The contribution of that we made basically had a very similar net impact. There maybe some new ones differences. And in terms of FivePoint's profitability going forward, I think you look to the numbers that come out from FivePoint independently as it is to sort of itself as an independent entity, very much part of our construct. So I think that what you're seeing is very similar to what we articulated as part of an IPO process, but just not what the fruition of the IPO process. And the combination that we've engineered in anticipation of something in the future is about creating efficiencies and effectiveness and growing this large-scale blue-chip operating platform for large-scale community development.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then second question. Just going back to some of the margin guidance. And so understand the operating margin flat to down 50. If I look at the gross margin guidance specifically and kind of look at midpoints and combined with some of the backlog conve
componenttext: And then second question. Just going back to some of the margin guidance. And so understand the operating margin flat to down 50. If I look at the gross margin guidance specifically and kind of look at midpoints and combined with some of the backlog conversion numbers, it looks like the guide is effectively towards the lower end of the 23 to 24 for gross margins. And again, understand there's some offsets on better SG&A control. But just curious what are -- what's driving that difference in -- are driving you towards the lower end of the gross margin guide compared to 3 or 6 months ago?

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, I think that what we articulated is a slow and steady growth recovery environment that is defined housing. But a lot of choppiness along the way. And I guess, if there's a representation of the choppiness we're talking about, it's the way that
componenttext: Well, look, I think that what we articulated is a slow and steady growth recovery environment that is defined housing. But a lot of choppiness along the way. And I guess, if there's a representation of the choppiness we're talking about, it's the way that the first quarter evolved kind of us a surprise to everyone, said raised interest rates starting January 1 right out of the suits at the beginning of the year, the capital markets tanked and it created some lack of confidence in the consumer. I think, generally speaking, you can't time where the choppiness actually exist. And so we left a fairly wide range as we gave guidance at the beginning of the year. We're probably trending to the lower parts of that range. But I think it drives from of the choppiness that's embedded in the system and the way that the year started out. And so at the end of the day, I think this is well within kind of the range that we articulated. I don't think it should be of any concern that we're trending towards the lower part of that range. And in fact, it's exactly why we gave the range that we did, recognizing that there are some tugs and pulls to the downside, as well as to the upside. But we still believe very strongly that the trend is upward.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And if this, I guess, if we are looking at the 2 next quarter, is this something where this is just a lack of pricing power that you would have anticipated? Or will you actually see incentives pick up in what's delivered over the next 2 quarters?

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think -- this is Rick. It's a combination of several factors. Choppiness, as Stuart says. We are seeing some labor price increases out in the field and that's going through our product. certainly, the building material manufacturers are trying to get mo
componenttext: I think -- this is Rick. It's a combination of several factors. Choppiness, as Stuart says. We are seeing some labor price increases out in the field and that's going through our product. certainly, the building material manufacturers are trying to get more for their product as well. That, combined with the slowing of sales price increases, has caused our margins to compress a little bit. As you step back from that, I'll say that they're still very healthy margin. We're very much focused on operating margin. if we can get the incremental deliveries, you'll see the play on operating margin, and that's really how we're operating the company. We are -- we continued to benefit from some land assets that we bought in prior years. But when we are replacing those line assets in a bit higher land cost basis around it through. So it's a combination of all those things that has an impact on gross margin.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And let me just, in this context, remind one thing that I said in the early, in my initial remarks. And that is we tend to look at national numbers. Even the roll off Lennar's numbers are a national rollup across the country. We're actually dealing with a
componenttext: And let me just, in this context, remind one thing that I said in the early, in my initial remarks. And that is we tend to look at national numbers. Even the roll off Lennar's numbers are a national rollup across the country. We're actually dealing with a lot of very, very different markets that roll up and sometimes give some kind of quirky rollup results. And so each market is operating very independently, is finding that the volatility in its unique market can sometimes relate to jobs, can sometimes relate to the macro environment, can sometimes relate to the international environment. And so you're seeing a rollup of all of those trend. So let's not forget that these are a lot of local markets that are operating very independently.

componenttext: This is actually Tim Daly on for an issue. My first question is kind of touching back with what I'd be was discussing the Multifamily business. So I noticed that you mentioned a that you kind of started in the Multifamily business by gathering market data and the market intelligence of that you had via the single-family operations. Does that mean that you traditionally targeting this a market in Multifamily as currently operating out of single-family and how does this dynamic contract, if that's the case?

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I wouldn't think of it exactly that way, although that is -- we are all targeting the same basic buyer just it's kind of depends on what the appetite of the buyer is at the moment in time. But I think that what we were articulating is that our keen un
componenttext: No, I wouldn't think of it exactly that way, although that is -- we are all targeting the same basic buyer just it's kind of depends on what the appetite of the buyer is at the moment in time. But I think that what we were articulating is that our keen understanding of each local market gave us an advantage as a new entrant to understanding where the demand actually lay and what the opportunities set was. It also give us a very sensitive group of tentacles in the market as to where activities was evolving. So it enabled us to avoid the markets that were perhaps getting a little bit too hot while gearing towards the market that had the most -- the deepest set of opportunities. So I would say that the Multifamily group has interacted very symbiotically with the for-sale group. And it's really worked to our benefit developing a long-term strategy.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me add a little bit on that, Mark. If you look at the first-time buyer, they are generally focused on the cost of affordability, suburban type of opportunities that require a little bit longer commute for them to get to where they work center is. And
componenttext: Let me add a little bit on that, Mark. If you look at the first-time buyer, they are generally focused on the cost of affordability, suburban type of opportunities that require a little bit longer commute for them to get to where they work center is. And our Multifamily operations, what we focus on and very transit oriented location, suburban, urban, a little bit urban, very location specific for folks that can't or may choose not to buy, but want to rent and they want to be in a live/work/play type of environment. So we really got to discrete strategies going on right now to capture that person that's in that first time buyer world.

headline: Lennar Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, let's remember that we're always competing as a for-sale homebuilder against the rental markets and perhaps, more importantly, against the existing home markets. So we've been pricing against rental rates for decades. And the fact that we happ
componenttext: Well, look, let's remember that we're always competing as a for-sale homebuilder against the rental markets and perhaps, more importantly, against the existing home markets. So we've been pricing against rental rates for decades. And the fact that we happen to be producing some of those rental communities in our markets is incidental. The fact is in none of our markets are we a dominant factor. To the contrary, we might have a community or 2 in any of the markets in which we operate in. And our homebuilding operation and pricing per se operates very independently from the way that where pricing rental rates. I would say to steer clear of viewing those, to any kind of relationship in rental rates for-sale pricing as interdependent as it relates to our management team pricing either one.
